annotation.TEXT: Much like a few of the other bosses, Quick Man is virtually the same as before. Given the trajectory on Bomb Man's attacks however, this fight is made more difficult than it needs to be. In the very least, you can punish him a bit when he constantly runs into one of the ledges/walls, but you won't get that opportunity for very long.

Metal Man himself isn't much different from his original counterpart. The only difficulty from this fight generally comes from Elec Man's own single-shot per screen limit. Metal Man will also occasionally jump to the opposite side of the room for no given reason (even though he's usually only supposed to do so whenever you get close to him).

Elec Man controls roughly the same way that Fire Man and Ice Man do (although he may be a bit faster overall). While his version of the Thunder Beam doesn't go in three directions, it's still relatively fast and has a large hit-box. It also produces a four-way spread shot when an enemy is killed by it.

Surprisingly enough, Bomb Man is also one of the more enjoyable characters to use in-game (at least, for this stage anyways). His Hyper Bomb now explodes on-contact with enemies and surfaces, giving off multiple hits from the explosions in the process. Needless to say, this is a great improvement.

Dickish enemy placement right here. You're supposed to fire at them when the one in front is close enough so that he springs further up to the ceiling, stalling its movements so the one behind it can get in-sync with it. But really, that's the most convoluted way imaginable of getting through this room.

Quick transition up ahead. This is mostly to skip by some farming I did on the Mole enemies, since they constantly respawn and you can kill them all fairly quickly thanks to the Thunder Beam's spread-shot. Then again, that doesn't make this process is any less tedious. By comparison to the original games, enemies are extremely stingy when it comes to dropping health. It took me a good 2 or so minutes to get back up to full life, even with the amount of enemies here.

Okay...What the hell is this? I know I've made comparisons to Super Mario World before, but this is literally the Grinder hazard from that game. Do I even need to point out how wrong this is? Sprite-clashing issues aside, it's scaled up to the point where the quality is heavily degraded. Could they not have just resized one of those gears that the Pierobots ride on? It would be equally lazy, but it still would have looked a million times better than this.

The only downside is that the Thunder Beam actually has a cool-down timer of sorts (which generally means you can only have one shot on-screen at the same time, and even then, you won't be able to fire another shot until a second or so after the first one goes away). The damage output on it can also be rather inconsistent, if mainly due to its multi-hit capabilities when going through enemies.
Not-so-welcome however are the return of the lasers. They're not quite as rough to deal with as the original ones, but they can still mess you over if you aren't constantly on the move.

I honestly never thought I would say this, but Quick Man's stage is actually the most tolerable level in the entire game. Aside from being shorter than the other stages, it doesn't have any gimmicks that cause you to wait around for very long (thankfully so, considering the lasers are back with full force here).

In the very least though, they did something a bit different by giving the lasers another new function (as seen here). They're still instant kills, but at least you can actually see them coming ahead of time.

Time to finally finish up with the eight main Robot Master stages. Metal Man's level isn't exactly enjoyable, but it's definitely a step up when compared to the other stages (barring a few annoying design choices here and there).
